Right, tests fib and decap failed on these new changes.

I suggest small fix instead of revert, add "[asic_index]" in get_fib_info method for lines:
- oports.append([str(duts_mg_facts**[asic_index]**['minigraph_ptf_indices'][x]) for x in po[ifname]['members']])
- oports.append([str(duts_mg_facts**[asic_index]**['minigraph_ptf_indices'][ifname.split('.')[0]])])
- oports.append([str(duts_mg_facts**[asic_index]**['minigraph_ptf_indices'][ifname])])

I already tested it. Fib and decap tests passed

FYI - [PR# 5027](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/5027) also broke fib and IP decap tests on T2 Voq chassis.  Fix was:
```
diff --git a/tests/common/fixtures/fib_utils.py b/tests/common/fixtures/fib_utils.py
index 6091bdda..70979484 100644
--- a/tests/common/fixtures/fib_utils.py
+++ b/tests/common/fixtures/fib_utils.py
@@ -111,14 +111,20 @@ def get_t2_fib_info(duthosts, duts_cfg_facts, duts_mg_facts):
                                     if remote_neigh_intf.startswith('PortChannel'):
                                         # The nexthop is a system lag.
                                         if dut_port_channels[remote_duthost_name].has_key(remote_neigh_intf):
-                                            oports.append([str(remote_dut_mg_facts['minigraph_ptf_indices'][x])
-                                                          for x in dut_port_channels[remote_duthost_name][remote_neigh_intf]['members']])
+                                            oport_list = []
+                                            for a_member in dut_port_channels[remote_duthost_name][remote_neigh_intf]['members']:
+                                                for a_asic_mg_facts in remote_dut_mg_facts:
+                                                    if a_member in a_asic_mg_facts['minigraph_port_indices']:
+                                                        oport_list.append(str(a_asic_mg_facts['minigraph_ptf_indices'][a_member]))
+                                            oports.append(oport_list)
                                         else:
                                             pytest_assert(False, "Coundn't find {} in the config of {}".format(
                                                remote_neigh_intf, remote_duthost_name) )
                                     else:
                                         # The nexthop is a system neighbor.
-                                        oports.append([str(remote_dut_mg_facts['minigraph_ptf_indices'][remote_neigh_intf])])
+                                        for a_asic_mg_facts in remote_dut_mg_facts:
+                                            if remote_neigh_intf in a_asic_mg_facts['minigraph_port_indices']:
+                                                oports.append([str(a_asic_mg_facts['minigraph_ptf_indices'][remote_neigh_intf])])
                                 else:
                                     oports.append([str(mg_facts[asic_index]['minigraph_ptf_indices'][ifname])])
                                     skip = False

```

> -                                            oports.append([str(remote_dut_mg_facts['minigraph_ptf_indices'][x])
> -                                                          for x in dut_port_channels[remote_duthost_name][remote_neigh_intf]['members']])
> +                                            oport_list = []
> +                                            for a_member in dut_port_channels[remote_duthost_name][remote_neigh_intf]['members']:

> -                                        oports.append([str(remote_dut_mg_facts['minigraph_ptf_indices'][remote_neigh_intf])])

> ```

> @svelamal Can you improve the PR title? `Test script modification` is too generic.

Hi Xin,
       Current test script had an issue where it did not scale beyond 1K nexthops and in case of Cisco-8000 platform, it has to go up to 16K nexthops to cause CRM resource exhaustion. We have done modification in wait time and how it is called to accommodate this scaled nexthop number. We have kept the changes specific to Cisco-8000 platform so that it does not affect other platforms.  I will ask PR submitter to update this in PR description.

ERR sonic_yang: Data Loading Failed:All Keys are not parsed in TACPLUS#012dict_keys(['global'])\n"] I met this failure before during my local test, it is because configDB contains empty table which result the test does not pass yang validation. However, previous generic_config_updater/test_aaa.py tests will also validate yang each time. So previous passing test, such as test_aaa_tc4_remove PASSED, means there is no empty table during the testing environment, otherwise it will fail anyway. So it confused me that why the testing environment was changed unexpected during the test somehow.

I did some research and found that the GCU will first sort the json_change to make sure it follows yang model rules. When some sorting doesn't comfort to the yang model rules, it will stop current sorting and just try other sorting method.
The log analyzer caught the ERR and fail immediately.
To fix GCU test, I can add disable log analyzer for GCU tests.

If that is the case, how we can estimate how many fdb entries are available? How the monitor should work and alert if the fdb table reaches the threshold?

> If that is the case, how we can estimate how many fdb entries are available? How the monitor should work and alert if the fdb table reaches the threshold?

Though hardware FDB counter is statistical-based, It is still fairly accurate with +/- 1 entry tolerance i.e.) inaccuracy of (1/622417*100). The problem is, the test script searching for exact count match each one increase or decrease. Once in a while, it is not going to have difference of 1 entry out of total 622417  entries due to hash function involved in hardware table offset calculation.  In nutshell, it is still more than good enough accuracy to use for CRM monitor which generates the syslog threshold messages based on percentage.

> @yejianquan - thanks for pointing this out. We don't have any single asic DUT's and thus did not test it out. Have pushed a change that should work for single asic as well

@sanmalho-git in #5192 @smaheshm taught me a more decent way to support both single-asic and multi-asic devices, I think that's the way it is supposed to be.

The issue here is that in min T2 topology (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/vars/topo_t2_2lc_min_ports-masic.yml) we have only 1 LAG per asic. That is why we need to look at all the LAGs in the linecard- where outgoing LAG is on the asic under test, but the incoming LAG could be on any other asic in the linecard.

> The issue here is that in min T2 topology (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/vars/topo_t2_2lc_min_ports-masic.yml) we have only 1 LAG per asic. That is why we need to look at all the LAGs in the linecard- where outgoing LAG is on the asic under test, but the incoming LAG could be on any other asic in the linecard.

@sanmalho-git I looked into your T2 topology, and understand what you need,  
`mg_facts = asichost.get_extended_minigraph_facts(tbinfo)` is the decent way to find the target portchannel which we're going to update the members of it under a certain asic.
For your case, please refactor it a little bit:
I used to choose 2 portchannels with at least two members, one as input, another as output. 
It's for simplicity's sake, you know, the input portchannel is not updated in following steps, there's no need to make sure it have at least 2 members.
We can liberalize restriction, only find 1 portchannel with at least 2 members as output, and find another input from global mg_facts with no limitation.
I think this will keep this test case much more readable and maintainable.
@yejianquan - rebased and incorporated your review comments in the latest commit.

Hi @sanmalho-git, I don't get why
peer_ip_pc_pair and pcs use dut_mg_facts, while out_pc use mg_fact still?
I'm questioning because I saw this test fail on my multi-asic device, where it tried to delete pc with config_portchannel_member, but the pc is not even on the namespace passed inside.

For the test we require 2 PC's - one that is going to send traffic (in_pc) and one that the traffic is going to egress out (out_pc). The out_pc is the portchannel on which the test will add/remove members. 

in_pc can be any portchannel on the DUT (regardless of the asic). For T2 min topology (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/vars/topo_t2_2lc_min_ports-masic.yml) we only have 1 portchannel per asic. So, we use dut_mg_facts instead of mg_facts.  There is no command on the DUT being done for in_pc.

out_pc though has to be on the same asic as 'enum_dut_asic_index', as otherwise the commands to remove/add ports to this portchannel (that use asichost) would fail.

Hope this helps

This PR is in Draft state. can you please share the plan to commit this PR to master? 
Are these planned to be validated on Virtual platform (VS) only? 
 
Most of the control path tests regarding macsec are limited test coverage within the scope of properties verification into DBs. In my opinion these test cases need to be extended at system behavior functional level.
Such as,
Macsec on VRF interface.
Rekey behavior
Fallback CKN feature
Macsec packet without encryption (i.e when policy = INTEGRITY_ONLY)
Key server selection with higher and lower priority value
Macsec traffic resumes when interface administrative status shutdown and resume
Macsec feature's behavior on config reload, fastboot and LC reload
send_sci true/false etc
Counters and stat based test.
Platform agnostic tests for check mka session(Currently it is limited to VM)
 
The macsec test plan(https://github.com/Pterosaur/sonic-mgmt/blob/macsec_platform/docs/testplan/MACsec-test-plan.md#) covers very few of them under functional area.
 
Is there a plan to document and validate the above-mentioned MACSec functional area/scenarios? If so, can you please share the relevant document, test scripts etc.

This PR is been developed. We plan that there is a community review meeting to MACsec test plan doc this month and  we will release this PR about next month.

In this PR, we focused on our scenario that MACsec will be only enabled on Ethernet Port so we don't have a short-term plan to support the VRF port. But other suggestions are very useful and we are considering to add them into this PR. All related document will be added to the document you mentioned by (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/4885).
